reasoning:
First things first, Amazon isn’t in my circle of competence. I like simple, proven businesses – Coca-Cola, See’s Candies, insurance or railroads – not a sprawling mix of e-commerce, cloud computing, advertising and logistics. If I don’t understand the economics, I don’t own the stock.

On moat, you get mixed signals. Operating margins look strong but ROE averages just 6.8% and only 0 out of 10 periods above 15%. High performance stability suggests some scale advantage, but inconsistent earnings growth and erratic returns tell me the competitive edge is neither durable nor predictable.

Management has shown visionary guts – I tip my hat to Jeff Bezos – yet capital allocation is all reinvestment, minimal dividends or buybacks. I prefer teams that behave like owners, returning excess cash when opportunities fade; Amazon plows every dollar back into the business, often at low returns on invested capital (just 2.2% ROIC today).

Financially, the balance sheet carries a heavy 2.1 debt-to-equity load and ROE under 7%. Earnings swing wildly; owner earnings turned negative in the DCF model, yielding a ludicrous negative intrinsic value and a margin of safety of –105%. That’s a red flag waving in the breeze.

Valuation looks stretched. My three-stage DCF spits out a negative intrinsic value under conservative assumptions. Buying here is like paying the farmer for seed before seeing any crop.

As for the long term, cloud computing may prosper but retail is a low-margin business exposed to fierce competition. Regulatory scrutiny and slim margins in consumer retail make this less attractive than simple, reliable cash cows.

Compare this to my investments in Apple – which I own for its consumer franchise, not its chips – or Coca-Cola with its steady moat. I’d rather own a wonderful business at a fair price than a complex one at any price. So on Amazon, I say no.

fundamental_analysis.details: Weak ROE of 6.8%; High debt to equity ratio of 2.1; Strong operating margins; Current ratio data not available

consistency_analysis.details: Inconsistent earnings growth pattern; Total earnings growth of 118.4% over past 10 periods

moat_analysis.details: Inconsistent ROE: only 0/10 periods >15%; Decent operating margins (avg: 48.2%) suggest some competitive advantage; High performance stability (85.2%) suggests strong competitive moat

book_value_analysis.details: Consistent book value per share growth (Buffett's favorite metric)

management_analysis.details: No significant new stock issuance detected; No or minimal dividends paid

details: Using three-stage DCF: Stage 1 (7.3%, 5y), Stage 2 (3.6%, 5y), Terminal (2.5%)
